TypeSignature.Value: .class public auto ansi abstract beforefieldinit DrawingContext extends System.Windows.Threading.DispatcherObject implements class System.IDisposable
Public MustInherit Class DrawingContext Inherits DispatcherObject Implements IDisposable
public ref class DrawingContext abstract : System::Windows::Threading::DispatcherObject, IDisposable
type DrawingContext = class inherit DispatcherObject interface IDisposable

Docs.summary: Describes visual content using draw, push, and pop commands.

remarks.format:
## Remarks Use a <xref:System.Windows.Media.DrawingContext> to populate a <xref:System.Windows.Media.Visual> or a <xref:System.Windows.Media.Drawing> with visual content.
Although the <xref:System.Windows.Media.DrawingContext> draw methods appear similar to the draw methods of the <xref:System.Drawing.Graphics?displayProperty=nameWithType> type, they function very differently: <xref:System.Windows.Media.DrawingContext> is used with a retained mode graphics system, while the <xref:System.Drawing.Graphics?displayProperty=nameWithType> type is used with an immediate mode graphics system. When you use a <xref:System.Windows.Media.DrawingContext> object's draw commands, you are actually storing a set of rendering instructions (although the exact storage mechanism depends on the type of object that supplies the <xref:System.Windows.Media.DrawingContext>) that will later be used by the graphics system; you are not drawing to the screen in real-time. For more information about how the Windows Presentation Foundation (WPF) graphics system works, see [WPF Graphics Rendering Overview](~/docs/framework/wpf/graphics-multimedia/wpf-graphics-rendering-overview.md).
You never directly instantiate a <xref:System.Windows.Media.DrawingContext>; you can, however, acquire a drawing context from certain methods, such as <xref:System.Windows.Media.DrawingGroup.Open%2A?displayProperty=nameWithType> and <xref:System.Windows.Media.DrawingVisual.RenderOpen%2A?displayProperty=nameWithType>.
## Examples The following example retrieves a <xref:System.Windows.Media.DrawingContext> from a <xref:System.Windows.Media.DrawingVisual> and uses it to draw a rectangle.
[!code-csharp[drawingvisualsample#101](~/samples/snippets/csharp/VS_Snippets_Wpf/DrawingVisualSample/CSharp/Window1.xaml.cs#101)] [!code-vb[drawingvisualsample#101](~/samples/snippets/visualbasic/VS_Snippets_Wpf/DrawingVisualSample/visualbasic/window1.xaml.vb#101)]
The next example demonstrates the <xref:System.Windows.Media.DrawingContext.PushOpacity%2A>, <xref:System.Windows.Media.DrawingContext.PushEffect%2A>, and <xref:System.Windows.Media.DrawingContext.Pop%2A> commands. The <xref:System.Windows.Media.DrawingContext> is obtained from a <xref:System.Windows.Media.DrawingGroup> and displayed using an <xref:System.Windows.Controls.Image> control.
[!code-csharp[DrawingContext_procedural_snip#PushEffectExampleWholePage](~/samples/snippets/csharp/VS_Snippets_Wpf/DrawingContext_procedural_snip/CSharp/PushEffectExample.cs#pusheffectexamplewholepage)] [!code-vb[DrawingContext_procedural_snip#PushEffectExampleWholePage](~/samples/snippets/visualbasic/VS_Snippets_Wpf/DrawingContext_procedural_snip/visualbasic/pusheffectexample.vb#pusheffectexamplewholepage)]

Docs.summary: Closes the and flushes the content. Afterward, the cannot be modified.

remarks.format: ## Remarks A <xref:System.Windows.Media.DrawingContext> must be closed before its content can be rendered, but after it has been closed, it cannot be modified. This call does not require all Push calls to have been Popped.

Docs.exception: This object has already been closed or disposed.

Docs.param: The brush with which to fill the ellipse. This is optional, and can be . If the brush is , no fill is drawn.
The pen with which to stroke the ellipse. This is optional, and can be . If the pen is , no stroke is drawn.
The location of the center of the ellipse.
The horizontal radius of the ellipse.
The vertical radius of the ellipse.
Docs.summary: Draws an ellipse with the specified and .

remarks.format: ## Remarks The brush and the pen can both be `null`. If the brush is `null`, then no fill is performed. If the pen is `null`, then no stoke is performed. If both the pen and the brush are `null`, then the drawing is not visible.

Docs.param: The media to draw.
The region in which to draw .
Docs.summary: Draws a video into the specified region.

remarks.format: ## Remarks Note that the media will be stretched to fit inside the area defined by the rectangle parameter. If rectangle and media have different aspect ratios, distortion will occur. For more control over how media is used to fill an area, use the <xref:System.Windows.Media.DrawingContext.DrawRectangle%2A> command to draw a rectangle and fill it with a <xref:System.Windows.Media.VisualBrush> that contains media.

Docs.permission: to display media that you do not have or access for. Associated enumeration: .

Public MustOverride Sub Pop ()
public: abstract void Pop();
abstract member Pop : unit -> unit

Docs.summary: Pops the last opacity mask, opacity, clip, effect, or transform operation that was pushed onto the drawing context.

remarks.format:
## Remarks Once an operation is popped, it is no longer applied to subsequent drawing commands.
## Examples The following example shows the effect of the <xref:System.Windows.Media.DrawingContext.Pop%2A> command.
[!code-csharp[DrawingContext_procedural_snip#PopExampleWholePage](~/samples/snippets/csharp/VS_Snippets_Wpf/DrawingContext_procedural_snip/CSharp/PopExample.cs#popexamplewholepage)] [!code-vb[DrawingContext_procedural_snip#PopExampleWholePage](~/samples/snippets/visualbasic/VS_Snippets_Wpf/DrawingContext_procedural_snip/visualbasic/popexample.vb#popexamplewholepage)]
The following illustration shows this example's output:
![Rectangles drawn with different opacity values](~/add/media/graphicsmm-drawingcontextpopexample.gif "Rectangles drawn with different opacity values")

Docs.param: The opacity factor to apply to subsequent drawing commands. This factor is cumulative with previous operations.
Docs.summary: Pushes the specified opacity setting onto the drawing context.

remarks.format:
## Remarks The opacity is blended into all subsequent drawing commands until it is removed by the <xref:System.Windows.Media.DrawingContext.Pop%2A> command.
## Examples The following example demonstrates the <xref:System.Windows.Media.DrawingContext.PushOpacity%2A>, <xref:System.Windows.Media.DrawingContext.PushEffect%2A>, and <xref:System.Windows.Media.DrawingContext.Pop%2A> commands.
[!code-csharp[DrawingContext_procedural_snip#PushEffectExampleWholePage](~/samples/snippets/csharp/VS_Snippets_Wpf/DrawingContext_procedural_snip/CSharp/PushEffectExample.cs#pusheffectexamplewholepage)] [!code-vb[DrawingContext_procedural_snip#PushEffectExampleWholePage](~/samples/snippets/visualbasic/VS_Snippets_Wpf/DrawingContext_procedural_snip/visualbasic/pusheffectexample.vb#pusheffectexamplewholepage)]

MemberSignature.Value: public abstract void PushOpacity (double opacity, System.Windows.Media.Animation.AnimationClock opacityAnimations);
.method public hidebysig newslot virtual instance void PushOpacity(float64 opacity, class System.Windows.Media.Animation.AnimationClock opacityAnimations) cil managed
Public MustOverride Sub PushOpacity (opacity As Double, opacityAnimations As AnimationClock)
public: abstract void PushOpacity(double opacity, System::Windows::Media::Animation::AnimationClock ^ opacityAnimations);
abstract member PushOpacity : double * System.Windows.Media.Animation.AnimationClock -> unit

Docs.param: The opacity factor to apply to subsequent drawing commands. This factor is cumulative with previous operations.
The clock with which to animate the opacity value, or for no animation. This clock must be created from an that can animate values.
Docs.summary: Pushes the specified opacity setting onto the drawing context and applies the specified animation clock.

remarks.format: ## Remarks The opacity is blended into all subsequent drawing commands until it is removed by the <xref:System.Windows.Media.DrawingContext.Pop%2A> command.

MemberSignature.Value: public abstract void PushOpacityMask (System.Windows.Media.Brush opacityMask);
.method public hidebysig newslot virtual instance void PushOpacityMask(class System.Windows.Media.Brush opacityMask) cil managed
Public MustOverride Sub PushOpacityMask (opacityMask As Brush)
public: abstract void PushOpacityMask(System::Windows::Media::Brush ^ opacityMask);
abstract member PushOpacityMask : System.Windows.Media.Brush -> unit

Docs.param: The opacity mask to apply to subsequent drawings. The alpha values of this brush determine the opacity of the drawing to which it is applied.
Docs.summary: Pushes the specified opacity mask onto the drawing context.

remarks.format:
## Remarks The mask is applied to all subsequent drawing commands until it is removed by the <xref:System.Windows.Media.DrawingContext.Pop%2A> operation.
For more information about creating opacity masks, see [Opacity Masks Overview](~/docs/framework/wpf/graphics-multimedia/opacity-masks-overview.md).
